SARAH HANSEN: Welcome to
"Chalk Radio," a podcast
about inspired teaching at MIT.

I'm your host, Sarah Hansen,
from MIT OpenCourseWare.

In this episode, we'll be
talking about MIT's flight

school with two of its
instructors, Philip Greenspun
and Tina Srivastava.

In our conversation, they share
how a number of innovations

have made the course
incredibly popular,

both in and outside
of the MIT community.

Part of why we want to
highlight this class

is that its
evolution has allowed

for a nimbleness of
structure without sacrificing

the effectiveness
of its instruction.

It's truly fascinating
that something

as seemingly technical
as flight school

can take so many
different shapes.

I wanted to dig into how it's
possible to find flexibility

in instruction with
such high risks

and, also, what made this course
so successful at attracting
and preparing future pilots.

We'll pick up our conversation
with Philip and Tina explaining

what it means to have
access to flight school

and what it really
takes to take flight.

PHILIP GREENSPUN:
People have been

wanting to fly for
thousands of years,

and only in the
last 100 years has
it become a practical reality.

And the US is unique, in
that it's half or a third

of the price here and much
easier to do in the US

they're never going

have the ability just

Certificate, which means

the flight school.

hands on the controls,

fly around, land without
the instructor having

to touch anything

airplanes and helicopters.

intensive three-day program.

more interest in the program

TINA SRIVASTAVA:
So I got engaged

in the course 16.687, the
Private Pilot Ground School,

my doctorate at MIT,

and as we continued teach
the course, over time,

we discussed the
potential of changing

the structure of the
course, and last year

the structure of the course.

two-hour lectures

in the evenings over the
full spring semester,

it became the three-day
intensive course.

In the new learning
format, I think

the advantages are that the
students can focus exclusively
on this course for three days.

TINA SRIVASTAVA: So they're not
distracted with other courses

They're just focused and
living and breathing everything

level of engagement

set of advantages.

successful in many ways.

engaged a lot of

important about having
this class meet in person.

an online format,

to pass the test, you can
self-study successfully.

lecture halls and a university,

share with students

empowered as a pilot,

the idea of trying to

are not part of the

most important pieces

what the students are
interested in and engaged in.

three-day class, we also

have a number of breaks,

feedback also helps

taught the class

answer or provide

the slide presentation

was really there

how they go about creating
clear and useful instruction

on complex topics, and they

in the class,
weight and balance.

TINA SRIVASTAVA: For
weight and balance,

what you're talking about is how
you load the aircraft, in terms

of the fuel, the
passengers, the baggage,
and how that affects the flight.

And so we used a
physical model airplane

to really demonstrate the
effect on an airplane,

if your center of gravity was
too far aft on the airplane.

We also solicited input
from the classroom

regarding their weight
and weights of bags.

insights and tips

that whenever they're flying
to not necessarily trust

what their passengers
tell them is
the weight, their own weight.

So to be safety conscious,

calculate weight and balance

to do those calculations on

different ways

to approach the same
information and materials.

academic description of how

to calculate weight
and balance, but truly

how they would do
that as a pilot,
